ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cerebellopontine angle tumor (Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unilateral progressive high-frequency SNHL, reduced word recognition in the left ear, and retrocochlear pattern on acoustic reflexes; confirmed by MRI.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration given the reported subjective decline in the left ear.
To evaluate speech reception and recognition abilities, particularly to check for retrocochlear signs like disproportionately poor recognition.
To assess middle ear function and rule out conductive pathology.
To evaluate the acoustic reflex arc for signs of retrocochlear pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation reveals normal hearing in the right ear and a progressive, steeply sloping high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Word recognition is reduced in the left ear (76%). Tympanometry is normal bilaterally, but acoustic reflexes demonstrate a retrocochlear pattern with elevated or absent thresholds, particularly in the left ear and contralateral conditions, warranting medical referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal hearing (0-10 dB HL). Left ear: Normal 250-1000 Hz, sloping to mild loss at 2000 Hz, then steeply sloping to moderately-severe/severe loss at 3000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 7 dB, Left 25 dB (consistent with PTA). WRS: Right 100%, Left 76%.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Right ipsilateral normal. Left ipsilateral elevated/absent. Contralateral reflexes elevated or absent bilaterally. Reflex decay could not be measured due to elevated thresholds.

proposed_items: Referral to ENT for medical evaluation and MRI
counseling_actions: Explained that the pattern of hearing loss and reflex results warrants further medical investigation.
Physician counseled on options for tumor management: translabyrinthine surgical removal vs. gamma knife surgery.

escalation.rationale_short: Unilateral SNHL and retrocochlear reflex findings require MRI to rule out cerebellopontine angle tumor.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds following gamma knife surgery.

expected_outcome: MRI confirmed a cerebellopontine angle tumor on the left side.
Patient opted for gamma knife surgery for management of the tumor.
Postsurgical follow-up hearing testing was recommended.
